awd_titl_txt: RR:  EAGER Collaborative Research:  Building Dynamic Research Communities in Global Legal Studies
awd_abstract_narration:
Comparative and international legal approaches provide the foundation for future scientific innovation. Complex legal frameworks are increasingly offered as the solution to the most pressing issues of our time.  The issues transcend borders, levels of governance, and areas of policy expertise demanding coordination, collaboration, and convergence to create sustainable institutional solutions to these pressing societal needs.

This project pilots a new model for collaborative and convergent research communities in law and social sciences. The project aims to form the critical connections, commitments, and institutionalization to ensure a transformative change in how research on comparative and international law is designed and implemented, and how the findings and data from the research are disseminated.  To date, lack of transparency, limited accountability, poorly-sustained graduate mentorship, and an absence of a commonly-accepted platform for data sharing have led to a fragmented field and a large number of single-use data projects. In turn, this has hampered the ability to sustain research agendas resolving salient legal questions.  The project develops three collaborative components: data infrastructure, Idea Labs, and an Annual Research Workshop. Together, these institutional innovations will ensure the reproducibility, replicability, and generalizability of data in the field of law and social sciences, and they will create a new multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary collaborative team model that is better equipped to embrace the complexity and scope of global legal challenges.

por.por_cntn:
The project developed a new model for collaborative and convergent research communities in law and social sciences. Creating a robust and reliable data infrastructure and collaboration network in the field of law and social sciences is central to the project outcomes. At the heart of this project, is the creation of a network that enables researchers to innovate on the foundation of prior research leading to scientific advancement. The project developed the Global Law & Politics Network that consists of three collaborative components: data infrastructure, idea labs and an ongoing series of virtual global research workshops. Together, these institutional innovations ensure the reproducibility, replicability, and generalizability of data in the field of law and social sciences, and also creates a new multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary collaborative team model that is well equipped to embrace the complexity and scope of global legal challenges. The project included two in person Idea Labs that focused on critical components of the legal process and brought together scholars and practitioners possessing a diversity of methodological and legal expertise. The Network also included a two day online international workshop, an ongoing monthly workshop series and an annual international workshop hosted at the University of Bergen. These research workshops provide the critical connections, commitments and institutionalization to ensure a transformative change in how research is designed, implemented and the findings and data are disseminated. Research projects resulting from these workshops engaged with salient public policy questions from the protection of human rights to judicial authority in autocratic regimes.

 

The project outcomes also promote teaching, training and learning in the area of law and social sciences through innovations in research design, implementation and data management and accessibility, methods, and graduate mentorship and training. The Network facilitates teaching and educational opportunities and mentorship of junior faculty and graduate students through a bi-monthly workshop series for graduate students and early-career scholars. The online workshop format has also enabled greater accessibility and participation by underrepresented minorities and scholars from lower income countries. The project website creates the platform and infrastructure for research and education in this field, including a central data catalogue and pedagogical materials, all ensuring both scientific advancement and public awareness on global policy issues. The website and data catalogue enable wide use of law and social science data for scholars and researchers interested in replicating empirical analyses and developing informed policies. This centralization of law and social sciences data by our project fosters the systematic development of this scientific field – a resource that is also invaluable to the practitioners, educators, community organizations and the public who experience and work to resolve global legal challenges.
